elements.content: New CoII members of the family of multifunctional materials of general formula [DAMS]4[M2Co(C2O4)6]·2DAMBA·2H2O (MIII = Rh, Fe, Cr; DAMBA = para-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde and [DAMS+] = trans-4-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-1-methylpyridinium) have been isolated and characterized. Such new hybrid mixed metal oxalates are isostructural with the previously investigated containing ZnII, MnII, and NiII. This allows to preserve the exceptional second harmonic generation (SHG) activity, due to both the large molecular quadratic hyperpolarizability of [DAMS+] and the efficiency of the crystalline network which organizes [DAMS+] into head-to-tail arranged J-type aggregates, and to further tune the magnetic properties. In particular, the magnetic data of the RhIII derivative demonstrate that high spin octacoordinated CoII centers behave very similarly to the hexacoordinated CoII ones, being dominated by a large orbital contribution. The CrIII derivative is characterized by ferromagnetic CrIII−CoII interactions. Most relevantly, the FeIII compound is characterized by a moderate antiferromagnetic interaction between FeIII and CoII, resulting in a ferrimagnetic like structure. Its low temperature dynamic magnetic properties were found to follow a thermally activated behavior (τ0 = 8.6 × 10−11 s and ΔE = 21.4 K) and make this a candidate for the second oxalate-based single chain magnet (SCM) reported up to date, a property which in this case is coupled to the second order non linear optical (NLO) ones.

elements.content: The characterization of the CoII members of a family of mixed MII/MIII metal oxalates and J-aggregated organic chromophores showed a variety of magnetic behavior at low temperature. In particular, in the FeIII derivative the coexistence of high second harmonic generation (SHG) and slow magnetic relaxation of the magnetization at low temperature is observed, demonstrating the possibility of easily and rationally tune the magnetic properties of this class of systems without affecting the SHG efficiency.

elements.content: In the past years, hybrid inorganic−organic materials with interesting electrical, magnetic, emissive, and non-linear optical (NLO) properties have attracted the interest of the materials science community. In particular, the addition of a novel degree of freedom to NLO systems, namely, the magnetic one, opens a yet largely unexplored research field. Although some magnetic materials displaying efficient second harmonic generation (SHG) have been reported, hybrid inorganic−organic materials in which the magnetic properties can be easily and rationally tuned without affecting the SHG efficiency are still rare. In most multifunctional inorganic−organic hybrid materials the provider of the magnetic properties is the inorganic part, while the second-order NLO response more frequently originates from the organic counterpart. In these mixed systems changes of the inorganic framework often lead to severe structural changes of the whole crystal structure inducing nonobvious variations of the SHG efficiency of the hybrid material. However, in layered hybrid inorganic−organic crystalline materials structural distortions induced by changes of the magnetic ions into the inorganic layer can be easily absorbed without significantly altering the whole crystalline framework, making them particularly well suited for tuning in a rational way the magnetic properties without affecting the SHG efficiency. In this regard, we have recently reported the synthesis as well as the structural, magnetic, spectroscopic, and NLO characterization of a new promising family of magnetic and second-order NLO isostructural layered hybrid inorganic−organic materials of general formula [MIII 2MII(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2·2H2O (where MIII = Rh, Fe, Cr; MII = Mn, Zn, Ni; DAMBA = p-N(CH3)2C6H4CHO and [DAMS+] is the second order NLO chromophore trans-4-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-1-methylpyridinium cation; see Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past years, hybrid inorganic-organic materials with interesting electrical, magnetic, emissive, and non-linear optical (NLO) properties have attracted the interest of the materials science community. In particular, the addition of a novel degree of freedom to NLO systems, namely, the magnetic one, opens a yet largely unexplored research field. Although some magnetic materials displaying efficient second harmonic generation (SHG) have been reported, hybrid inorganic-organic materials in which the magnetic properties can be easily and rationally tuned without affecting the SHG efficiency are still rare. In most multifunctional inorganic-organic hybrid materials the provider of the magnetic properties is the inorganic part, while the second-order NLO response more frequently originates from the organic counterpart. In these mixed systems changes of the inorganic framework often lead to severe structural changes of the whole crystal structure inducing nonobvious variations of the SHG efficiency of the hybrid material. However, in layered hybrid inorganic-organic crystalline materials structural distortions induced by changes of the magnetic ions into the inorganic layer can be easily absorbed without significantly altering the whole crystalline framework, making them particularly well suited for tuning in a rational way the magnetic properties without affecting the SHG efficiency. In this regard, we have recently reported the synthesis as well as the structural, magnetic, spectroscopic, and NLO characterization of a new promising family of magnetic and second-order NLO isostructural layered hybrid inorganic-organic materials of general formula [MIII 2MII(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2⋅2H2O (where MIII = Rh, Fe, Cr; MII = Mn, Zn, Ni; DAMBA = p-N(CH3)2C6H4CHO and [DAMS+] is the second order NLO chromophore trans-4-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-1-methylpyridinium cation; see Scheme ).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="ic-2010-013076_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

This class of materials possesses some important structural features: it segregates layers of J-aggregated [DAMS+] NLO chromophores and of mixed metal oxalate stripes of MIII and MII cations which can be properly chosen to produce specific magnetic behaviors. The variety of magnetic properties which arises from different MIII/MII pairs does not affect the very high SHG efficiency. In view of this tunability of the magnetic properties and of the particular structural arrangement, we extended our investigation to the CoII members of this new class of hybrid mixed oxalates. The aim was to obtain a hybrid material with both high second order NLO properties and possibly Single Chain Magnet (SCM) ones. The latter are one-dimensional (1D) magnetic polymers whose magnetization relaxes slowly at low-temperatures and were the focus of intense research work in recent years, since the first discovery of this peculiar behavior in a cobalt-organic radical system. The presence between the inorganic layers of a large organic layer responsible for the second order NLO behavior makes this family of mixed MIII/MII metal oxalates particularly suited to obtain monodimensional magnetic behavior, since the organic layer strongly reduces the interchain interaction. However, the 1D systems containing the MnII ion previously investigated were characterized by weak intrachain exchange interactions, leading to reduced correlation lengths among the spins and hampering any possibility of obtaining SCM behavior. More promising results were obtained with the NiII derivatives, with improved intrachain exchange interactions. However, also for the stripes including NiII centers, no sign of slow relaxation of the magnetization down to 2 K could be detected. This was attributed to the competing nearest-neighbor and next-nearest-neighbor interactions, giving rise to a magnetic state in which the NiII sublattice gives no neat magnetic contribution. In summary, these latter results confirmed that exchange coupling interactions could be obtained in this class of new hybrid materials while retaining the superior second order NLO properties; therefore, the preparation and characterization of CoII derivatives was envisaged as an obvious extension. It is indeed well-known that, to obtain slow relaxation of the magnetization at low temperature, beyond a good isolation between adjacent magnetic chains, the second necessary property is a strong anisotropy of at least one magnetic center. In this respect both CoII and LnIII containing systems, with the large magnetic anisotropy imposed by these metal centers, are currently actively being investigated to obtain new SCM systems. Following this expectation recently a dysprosium-radical derivative has been shown to behave as a SCM at low temperature while keeping the features of a second order NLO active material. It is worth noting that the possibility of obtaining oxalate-based SCMs, in spite of their relatively weak exchange interactions, has been recently reported by Coronado and co-workers.

elements.content: In the present study, we will report on the structural, second-order NLO, and magnetic properties of the CoII derivatives of this new class of multifunctional hybrid mixed metal oxalates first investigated in our laboratories, and in particular on the simultaneous occurrence, in one of them, of SCM-like behavior at low temperature still maintaining the high second order and NLO response.
elements.clean_text: In the present study, we will report on the structural, second-order NLO, and magnetic properties of the CoII derivatives of this new class of multifunctional hybrid mixed metal oxalates first investigated in our laboratories, and in particular on the simultaneous occurrence, in one of them, of SCM-like behavior at low temperature still maintaining the high second order and NLO response.

elements.content: K3[M(C2O4)3]·nH2O (M = Rh, Cr, and Fe) were prepared according to the literature. [DAMS]I and Co(NO3)2·6H2O were purchased from Sigma−Aldrich and used without further purification. All relevant phases were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRPD) and FeIII 2CoII by single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were carried out in the Dipartimento di Chimica Inorganica, Metallorganica e Analitica “Lamberto Malatesta” of the University of Milano. M(II), M(III) analyses were performed in the Dipartimento di Chimica “U. Schiff”, University of Florence, by using a Perkin-Elmer Optima 2000 inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer. Electronic absorption spectra were recorded on a Jasco V-530 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures and Materials

K3[M(C2O4)3]⋅nH2O (M = Rh, Cr, and Fe) were prepared according to the literature. [DAMS]I and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. All relevant phases were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRPD) and FeIII 2CoII by single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were carried out in the Dipartimento di Chimica Inorganica, Metallorganica e Analitica "Lamberto Malatesta" of the University of Milano. M(II), M(III) analyses were performed in the Dipartimento di Chimica "U. Schiff", University of Florence, by using a Perkin-Elmer Optima 2000 inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer. Electronic absorption spectra were recorded on a Jasco V-530 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: In a 100 mL two-necked flask [DAMS]I (183.2 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated at 60 °C, and 0.5 mmol K3[M(C2O4)3]·nH2O (M = Rh, Fe, Cr), previously dissolved in 20 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), were added. The heating was turned off, and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (145.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), dissolved in CH3OH (2−3 mL), was added to the still hot solution. A brownish-black precipitate separated immediately as phase αMIII/CoII. After 1 h 30 min stirring at room temperature the solid was filtered, washed with a few drops of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), and dried under vacuum. Attempts to grow suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction failed. Phases αMIII/CoII were characterized by XRPD and found corresponding to αMIII/MII (MIII = Rh, Cr, Fe; MII = Zn, Mn, Ni).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Phases αMIII/CoII (M = Cr, Fe, Rh)

In a 100 mL two-necked flask [DAMS]I (183.2 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated at 60 °C, and 0.5 mmol K3[M(C2O4)3]⋅nH2O (M = Rh, Fe, Cr), previously dissolved in 20 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), were added. The heating was turned off, and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (145.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), dissolved in CH3OH (2-3 mL), was added to the still hot solution. A brownish-black precipitate separated immediately as phase αMIII/CoII. After 1 h 30 min stirring at room temperature the solid was filtered, washed with a few drops of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), and dried under vacuum. Attempts to grow suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction failed. Phases αMIII/CoII were characterized by XRPD and found corresponding to αMIII/MII (MIII = Rh, Cr, Fe; MII = Zn, Mn, Ni).

elements.content: In a 100 mL flask DAMBA (20.5 mg; 0.14 mmol) was added to the corresponding αCrIII/CoII or αFeIII/CoII phase (80.0 mg), prepared as above-reported, dissolved in 70 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated under reflux for 1 h 30 min and then cooled at room temperature. On standing overnight, the formation of a dark compound with a metallic luster was observed. After filtration, the compound was dried under vacuum. Crystals of FeIII 2CoII suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by leaving the solution at room temperature for 3 days.

[M2Co(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2⋅2H2O (M = Cr, Fe)

The solution was heated under reflux for 1 h 30 min and then cooled at room temperature. On standing overnight, the formation of a dark compound with a metallic luster was observed. After filtration, the compound was dried under vacuum. Crystals of FeIII 2CoII suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by leaving the solution at room temperature for 3 days.

[Rh2Co(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2⋅2H2O

In a 100 mL flask DAMBA (80.0 mg; 0.55 mmol) was added to αRhIII/CoII phase (80.0 mg), prepared as above-reported, dissolved in 70 mL of H2O. The solution was heated under reflux for 1 h 30 min and then cooled at room temperature. On standing overnight, the formation of a dark compound with a metallic cluster was observed. After filtration, the compound was dried under vacuum. Crystals suitable for single crystal XRD analysis were obtained by leaving the solution at room temperature for 3 days.

Solid-State SHG by Kurtz−Perry Measurements.

The 1064 nm initial wavelength of a Nd:YAG pulsed laser beam was shifted to 1907 nm by stimulated scattering in a high-pressure hydrogen cell. A portion of this beam was directed on sample containing capillaries. The scattered radiation was collected by an elliptical mirror, filtered to select only the second-order contribution, and recollected with a Hamamatsu R5108 photomultiplier tube. SHG efficiency was evaluated by taking as reference the SHG signal of [DAMS][p-toluenesulfonate] or urea.

Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Measurements

A crystal of [Fe2Co(C2O4)6][DAMS]4⋅2DAMBA⋅2H2O was mounted on a glass fiber and collected on a Bruker SMART APEX 2 CCD area-detector diffractometer. Data collection was carried out in air at room temperature. Crystal data are reported in Table .

elements.content: Graphite-monochromatized Mo−Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation was used with the generator working at 50 kV and 30 mA. Orientation matrix was initially obtained from least-squares refinement on about 300 reflections measured in three different ω regions, in the range 0 < θ < 30°; cell parameters were eventually optimized on the position, determined after integration, of all reflections above 10 σ(I) level. 1080 frames, at 60 s per frame respectively, were collected with Δω = 0.5°. Sample−detector distance was set at 6 cm; an empirical absorption correction was applied (SADABS).

The powders of all phases analyzed were gently ground in an agate mortar and then cautiously deposited in the hollow of an aluminum holder equipped with a zero background plate with the aid of a glass slide. Diffraction data (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å) were collected on a vertical scan Philips PW1820 diffractometer with the generator operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Intensities were measured in the range 5 < 2θ < 35°, typically with step scans 0.02° (10 s/step).

XRPD Analysis

The powders of all phases analyzed were gently ground in an agate mortar and then cautiously deposited in the hollow of an aluminum holder equipped with a zero background plate with the aid of a glass slide. Diffraction data (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å) were collected on a vertical scan Philips PW1820 diffractometer with the generator operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Intensities were measured in the range 5 < 2θ < 35°, typically with step scans 0.02° (10 s/step).

elements.content: Direct current (DC) magnetic measurements were performed by using a Cryogenic S600 SQUID magnetometer operating between 2 and 300 K and with an applied field ranging from 0 to 6 T or with a QD MPMS working in the same range of temperature between 0 and 5 T. The latter instrument was also used to perform alternating current (AC) measurements at frequencies below 1 kHz in the temperature range 1.8−12 K. For higher frequencies (400−25000 Hz) and lower temperature (1.6−3.9 K) AC measurements have been performed using a home developed probe based on the Oxford Inst. MAGLAB platform. All the samples were prepared by grinding freshly filtered crystals and then wrapping the powder in a Teflon tape. Measurements were repeated also by pressing the sample in a pellet to check for possible orientation effects. Magnetic susceptibilities were corrected for diamagnetism by using Pascal’s constants. The diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder and the Teflon tape were independently measured and subtracted.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Direct current (DC) magnetic measurements were performed by using a Cryogenic S600 SQUID magnetometer operating between 2 and 300 K and with an applied field ranging from 0 to 6 T or with a QD MPMS working in the same range of temperature between 0 and 5 T. The latter instrument was also used to perform alternating current (AC) measurements at frequencies below 1 kHz in the temperature range 1.8-12 K. For higher frequencies (400-25000 Hz) and lower temperature (1.6-3.9 K) AC measurements have been performed using a home developed probe based on the Oxford Inst. MAGLAB platform. All the samples were prepared by grinding freshly filtered crystals and then wrapping the powder in a Teflon tape. Measurements were repeated also by pressing the sample in a pellet to check for possible orientation effects. Magnetic susceptibilities were corrected for diamagnetism by using Pascal's constants. The diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder and the Teflon tape were independently measured and subtracted.

elements.content: An Angular Overlap Model based program has been used to calculate the energy levels pattern of the CoII ion in different coordination environments. The anisotropic properties of the two lowest lying doublets were then fitted to an effective spin Hamiltonian using the Gerloch formula. The polar coordinates of the ligand atoms derived from the X-ray structure were used to model the octacoordinated system, and the ligand field parameters of the two oxygen groups at different bond lengths were set as follows: Dq1 = 1200 cm−1, Dq2 = 400 cm−1, ζ = −426 cm−1, B = 880 cm−1, C = 3500.0 cm−1 eπ/eσ = 0.2. For the sake of comparison, we also calculated the energy pattern and corresponding g values of an idealized octacoordinated system with the same polar coordinates and ligand atoms supposed at the same distances (i.e., with only one Dq parameters for all the eight ligand atoms). Finally, the energy pattern of a tetracoordinated system obtained by considering only the four ligands at shorter distance was calculated.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

An Angular Overlap Model based program has been used to calculate the energy levels pattern of the CoII ion in different coordination environments. The anisotropic properties of the two lowest lying doublets were then fitted to an effective spin Hamiltonian using the Gerloch formula. The polar coordinates of the ligand atoms derived from the X-ray structure were used to model the octacoordinated system, and the ligand field parameters of the two oxygen groups at different bond lengths were set as follows: Dq1 = 1200 cm-1, Dq2 = 400 cm-1, ζ = -426 cm-1, B = 880 cm-1, C = 3500.0 cm-1 eπ/eσ = 0.2. For the sake of comparison, we also calculated the energy pattern and corresponding g values of an idealized octacoordinated system with the same polar coordinates and ligand atoms supposed at the same distances (i.e., with only one Dq parameters for all the eight ligand atoms). Finally, the energy pattern of a tetracoordinated system obtained by considering only the four ligands at shorter distance was calculated.

elements.content: As already reported, the best synthetic method to obtain compounds of the family of mixed oxalates of general formula [MIII 2MII(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2·2H2O (where MIII = Rh, Fe, Cr; MII = Mn, Zn, Ni; DAMBA = p-N(CH3)2C6H4CHO, [DAMS+] = trans-4-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-1-methylpyridinium) consists in a two step procedure. In the first step intermediated αMIII/MII phases are obtained by mixing in water K3[M(C2O4)3]·nH2O (M = Rh, Fe, Cr), MII (M = Mn, Zn, Ni) salts and [DAMS]I. Despite the impossibility of isolating single crystals suitable for XRD characterization, αMIII/MII phases have been found to be isomorphous by XRPD analysis, and characterized by a strong SHG of the same order of magnitude of [DAMS][p-toluenesulfonate] (i.e., 1000 times that of urea) measured by the Kurtz−Perry method. In the second step, αMIII/MII phases are dissolved in H2O, added with DAMBA, and heated under reflux to produce compounds of this new family of hybrid mixed oxalates.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis, Spectroscopic, Second Order NLO, and Structural Characterization

As already reported, the best synthetic method to obtain compounds of the family of mixed oxalates of general formula [MIII 2MII(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2⋅2H2O (where MIII = Rh, Fe, Cr; MII = Mn, Zn, Ni; DAMBA = p-N(CH3)2C6H4CHO, [DAMS+] = trans-4-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-1-methylpyridinium) consists in a two step procedure. In the first step intermediated αMIII/MII phases are obtained by mixing in water K3[M(C2O4)3]⋅nH2O (M = Rh, Fe, Cr), MII (M = Mn, Zn, Ni) salts and [DAMS]I. Despite the impossibility of isolating single crystals suitable for XRD characterization, αMIII/MII phases have been found to be isomorphous by XRPD analysis, and characterized by a strong SHG of the same order of magnitude of [DAMS][p-toluenesulfonate] (i.e., 1000 times that of urea) measured by the Kurtz-Perry method. In the second step, αMIII/MII phases are dissolved in H2O, added with DAMBA, and heated under reflux to produce compounds of this new family of hybrid mixed oxalates.

elements.content: [MIII 2CoII(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2·2H2O (where M = Cr, Fe, Rh; hereafter indicated as CrIII 2CoII, FeIII 2CoII, RhIII 2CoII, respectively, or collectively as MIII 2CoII) were prepared by applying a slightly modified version of this two step method (see the Experimental Section). By the Kurtz−Perry method, working with a non-resonant wavelength of 1907 nm, all MIII 2CoII hybrid crystalline materials were found to be characterized by the same very high SHG (same order of magnitude of [DAMS][p-toluenesulfonate] working at the same incident wavelength).

elements.content: As reported for all the compounds of this family of mixed hybrid oxalates investigated so far, solid-state electronic absorption spectra of MIII 2CoII compounds show the superposition of two bands: a broad and strong band centered at 464 nm and a strong, narrow band at 568 nm. This latter has been identified as the fingerprint of J aggregation of the [DAMS+] chromophore. In acetonitrile solution MIII 2CoII compounds all show an absorption spectrum identical to that of [DAMS]I, with an absorption band at 471 nm because of the disruption of the ordered J aggregates by dissolution in a polar organic solvent.

elements.content: MIII 2CoII compounds have been found by XRPD to be isomorphous (see ) to the previously structurally characterized congeners of this family (MIII = Cr, Fe, Rh; MII = Mn, Ni, Zn) crystallizing in the polar acentric Fdd2 space group. The crystalline structure of the FeIII 2CoII compound was solved by XRD analysis of suitable single crystals (see the Experimental Section). The large asymmetric unit contains two independent [DAMS+] ions, one DAMBA, one water molecule, three oxalate anions, one FeIII atom in a general position, and one CoII in a 2-fold special position.
elements.clean_text: MIII 2CoII compounds have been found by XRPD to be isomorphous (see ) to the previously structurally characterized congeners of this family (MIII = Cr, Fe, Rh; MII = Mn, Ni, Zn) crystallizing in the polar acentric Fdd2 space group. The crystalline structure of the FeIII 2CoII compound was solved by XRD analysis of suitable single crystals (see the Experimental Section). The large asymmetric unit contains two independent [DAMS+] ions, one DAMBA, one water molecule, three oxalate anions, one FeIII atom in a general position, and one CoII in a 2-fold special position.

elements.content: Differently from other mixed layered metal-oxalates of [DAMS+], all these hybrid materials are characterized by layers of mixed metal oxalates based on an organic−inorganic 2D framework, rather than a purely inorganic one. The inorganic part of this layer is composed by the metal ions and the coordinated oxalates, forming infinite stripes (∼14 Å large) (see Figure ), elongated along the c axis. The MII cations are bound to four oxalate groups in a distorted square anti prismatic coordination environment while the MIII cations are octahedrally coordinated by three oxalate groups. One of these latter stretches out from the stripe, whereas the other two oxalates bridge MIII and MII, forming a peculiar -MII-(MIII)2-MII-(MIII)2-MII- 1D quite unusual motif. Details about the metal to oxygen bond length of this rather uncommon, at least for CoII and NiII, cubic antiprismatic coordination are reported in Table ; notably the Co environment is closer to that of Ni rather than that of Mn in the corresponding FeIII 2MII compounds.

elements.content: As already reported for this family of mixed metal oxalates, each pair of stripes is spaced by ∼10 Å and shifted by 1/2 along c, producing a mismatch of the lateral branches, as shown in Figure (top). The volume between the stripes is used to accommodate bridges formed by DAMBA and water molecules. Such a two-dimensional (2D) layer is held together by medium/strong O−H---O hydrogen bonds (Oxalate---water---DAMBA, water acting as HB donor with O---O distances of about 2.9 Å) and weaker C−H---O hydrogen bonds (DAMBA---oxalate, DAMBA being the donor). This entanglement produces a compact but flexible mixed organic/inorganic layer parallel to (100), where DAMBA acts as a fundamental building block, not just as a spacer. The mixed inorganic/organic layers are negatively charged, with a surface density of charge of about 0.008 e/Å2 (a charge of −4 spread over a surface of about 462 Å2, corresponding to the (1 0 0) plane). This perfectly fits the charge/area ratio obtained by a layer of tightly packed, as J aggregates, [DAMS+] ions. Hence, the overall structure contains alternating negatively and positively charged layers, all parallel to the [100] plane and stacking one on top of another along the a axis (Figure , bottom).

elements.content: The peculiar magnetic behavior introduced by CoII centers, which are well-known not to follow the Curie behavior, was first investigated by studying the MIII 2CoII compound containing the diamagnetic RhIII center. In general the introduction of RhIII centers is expected to produce weak magnetic interactions inside the chain so that an experimental determination of the effects on the magnetic properties of RhIII 2CoII could be attributable mainly to uncoupled CoII centers. This is in itself an interesting output of this investigation, since the octacoordinated geometry is very rare in CoII compounds and no report on the magnetic behavior of the CoII ion in this environment has, to the best of our knowledge, ever been reported. The χT versus T value (Figure ) measured at room temperature (3.1 emu K mol−1) is much higher than that for a spin-only value for S = 3/2, and indicates the persistence of a substantial unquenched orbital contribution in the square antiprismatic coordination, similar to what is usually reported for pseudo-octahedral CoII coordination. The decrease of χT observed on lowering temperature down to 100 K should be attributed for the same reason to depopulation effects of the levels arising from the splitting of the ground multiplet, since antiferromagnetic exchange interactions among CoII ions, which are far apart from each other (15.8 Å) have to be excluded. This latter point is confirmed by the magnetization curve as a function of field, which tends to saturate at a value in agreement with an effective S = 1/2 and an average g value g ave = 4.3 (M = 2.1 μB at 6 T and 2 K, inset of Figure ). This behavior resembles more that of the RhIII 2MnII compound, for which no interaction between the MnII centers were reported, than to that of the RhIII 2NiII compound, for which significant antiferromagnetic interactions were postulated. Furthermore, these results suggest that the magnetic behavior of this kind of octacoordinated CoII, characterized by two largely different bond lengths resembles more that of octahedral CoII (with largely unquenched orbital contribution) than that of tetrahedral CoII, characterized by an orbitally singlet ground state. To rationalize the observed properties we performed sample calculations on the basis of the Angular Overlap Model. Even if it is well-known that the anisotropic magnetic properties of CoII are dramatically affected by small variation of low-symmetry ligand field components, the results provided qualitative indication that the observed experimental behavior follows theoretical expectations. Indeed, for both tetracoordinated and octacoordinated CoII centers with ligands at the same distance, calculations provide an estimate of the quartet ground state splitting of about 15 cm−1, whereas for the octacoordinated systems characterized by four long coordination bonds the separation between the two ground doublets easily exceeds 50 cm−1, closer to the result expected for of an hexacoordinated pseudo-octahedral system. The same calculation also provide an estimate of the g values, suggesting that the ground doublet in RhIII 2CoII is actually characterized by a quite strong Ising character, with g x,y about ≈ 1.6 and g z ≈ 7.1.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

[RhIII 2CoII(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2⋅2H2O

The peculiar magnetic behavior introduced by CoII centers, which are well-known not to follow the Curie behavior, was first investigated by studying the MIII 2CoII compound containing the diamagnetic RhIII center. In general the introduction of RhIII centers is expected to produce weak magnetic interactions inside the chain so that an experimental determination of the effects on the magnetic properties of RhIII 2CoII could be attributable mainly to uncoupled CoII centers. This is in itself an interesting output of this investigation, since the octacoordinated geometry is very rare in CoII compounds and no report on the magnetic behavior of the CoII ion in this environment has, to the best of our knowledge, ever been reported. The χT versus T value (Figure ) measured at room temperature (3.1 emu K mol-1) is much higher than that for a spin-only value for S = 3/2, and indicates the persistence of a substantial unquenched orbital contribution in the square antiprismatic coordination, similar to what is usually reported for pseudo-octahedral CoII coordination. The decrease of χT observed on lowering temperature down to 100 K should be attributed for the same reason to depopulation effects of the levels arising from the splitting of the ground multiplet, since antiferromagnetic exchange interactions among CoII ions, which are far apart from each other (15.8 Å) have to be excluded. This latter point is confirmed by the magnetization curve as a function of field, which tends to saturate at a value in agreement with an effective S = 1/2 and an average g value g ave = 4.3 (M = 2.1 μB at 6 T and 2 K, inset of Figure ). This behavior resembles more that of the RhIII 2MnII compound, for which no interaction between the MnII centers were reported, than to that of the RhIII 2NiII compound, for which significant antiferromagnetic interactions were postulated. Furthermore, these results suggest that the magnetic behavior of this kind of octacoordinated CoII, characterized by two largely different bond lengths resembles more that of octahedral CoII (with largely unquenched orbital contribution) than that of tetrahedral CoII, characterized by an orbitally singlet ground state. To rationalize the observed properties we performed sample calculations on the basis of the Angular Overlap Model. Even if it is well-known that the anisotropic magnetic properties of CoII are dramatically affected by small variation of low-symmetry ligand field components, the results provided qualitative indication that the observed experimental behavior follows theoretical expectations. Indeed, for both tetracoordinated and octacoordinated CoII centers with ligands at the same distance, calculations provide an estimate of the quartet ground state splitting of about 15 cm-1, whereas for the octacoordinated systems characterized by four long coordination bonds the separation between the two ground doublets easily exceeds 50 cm-1, closer to the result expected for of an hexacoordinated pseudo-octahedral system. The same calculation also provide an estimate of the g values, suggesting that the ground doublet in RhIII 2CoII is actually characterized by a quite strong Ising character, with g  x,y  about ~ 1.6 and g z ~ 7.1.

elements.content: The χT versus T value for CrIII 2CoII derivative at room temperature (6.71 emu K mol-1) agrees quite well with the sum of the values of χT found for RhIII 2CoII (3.1 emu K mol-1, see above) and CrIII 2ZnII compounds (3.68 emu K mol−1 ), suggesting the weakness of the magnetic interaction between adjacent paramagnetic centers such as CoII and CrIII, whose effects are not observable at this temperature. In accordance with this the χT curve (Figure ) slowly decreases on cooling down to 200 K, in a way parallel with the decrease observed for the RhIII 2CoII derivative. The decrease of χT should thus be attributed to single ion effects of CoII ions, at least down to 200 K, while exchange coupling interactions are not effective in this temperature range. At lower temperatures, the plot of (χT Cr2Co − χT Rh2Co) versus T, which steadily increases with temperature, clearly testifies to the presence of ferromagnetic interactions, which results in a χT versus T curve passing through a quite sharp maximum at 4 K (7.9 emu K mol−1).

elements.content: The achievement of a ferromagnetic behavior of the CrIII/CoII chain is confirmed by the low temperature field dependent magnetization curves (inset of Figure ), which attains a saturation value of 8 μB, in agreement with what is expected for a full “spin-up” configuration on the basis of the saturation values observed for CrIII 2ZnII and RhIII 2CoII derivatives. The presence of a ferromagnetic interaction between CrIII and CoII centers at low temperatures is in agreement with what is reported for simple dinuclear and trinuclear cluster.

The presence of a ferromagnetic interaction between CrIII and CoII centers at low temperatures is in agreement with what is reported for simple dinuclear and trinuclear cluster.

elements.content: It is, however, to be noticed that both the relatively low maximum value of χT and the shape of the M versus H curve, attaining saturation only at quite high fields, points to exchange interactions weaker than those reported for other CrIII−CoII mixed oxalates. This behavior can also be due to the competing effects of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between CrIII ions, which were visible below 10 K in the CrIII 2ZnII derivative. The relative weakness of the exchange coupling interaction, coupled to the good isolation provided by the organic layer, responsible for the second order NLO activity, results in the absence of both magnetic long-range order and single-chain magnet behavior, confirmed by the absence of any imaginary components (χ′′) in the AC magnetic susceptibility.
elements.clean_text: It is, however, to be noticed that both the relatively low maximum value of χT and the shape of the M versus H curve, attaining saturation only at quite high fields, points to exchange interactions weaker than those reported for other CrIII-CoII mixed oxalates. This behavior can also be due to the competing effects of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between CrIII ions, which were visible below 10 K in the CrIII 2ZnII derivative. The relative weakness of the exchange coupling interaction, coupled to the good isolation provided by the organic layer, responsible for the second order NLO activity, results in the absence of both magnetic long-range order and single-chain magnet behavior, confirmed by the absence of any imaginary components (χ'') in the AC magnetic susceptibility.

elements.content: At room temperature the experimental value of χT (9.8 emu K mol−1) of FeIII 2CoII is lower than that expected assuming the three spins to be uncoupled, and considering the experimental values observed for RhIII 2CoII and FeIII 2ZnII. This suggests the presence of sizable antiferromagnetic interactions, already visible at this temperature, as confirmed by the marked decrease of χT by lowering the temperature (Figure ). This behavior can not be attributed to simple ligand field effects of CoII centers, since the corresponding, isostructural, RhIII 2CoII derivative shows a less marked temperature dependence of χT in the same range of temperatures. On further lowering the temperature χT passes through a minimum at 30 K (8.3 emu K mol−1) and then starts to increase, a behavior reminiscent of a ferrimagnetic like structure, which indicates that antiferromagnetic interactions result in a non compensation of the spins, obviously suggesting that they are active between FeIII and CoII ions. On further lowering the temperature a maximum in χT, which is field dependent because of saturation effects, is observed (9.8 emu K mol−1 at 4.2 K for H ≤ 1 KOe, including AC measurements). The antiparallel orientation of the spin on CoII and FeIII sub lattices because of the dominating antiferromagnetic interactions is confirmed by the field dependent magnetization curve recorded at 2 K (inset of Figure ), which saturates at about 8 μB, corresponding to the experimentally determined one for Msat(FeIII 2ZnII) − Msat(RhIII 2CoII). As a whole the observed behavior strongly resembles that observed for the FeIII 2MnII derivative and agrees with expectations of dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between CoII and FeIII mediated by oxalate bridges.

elements.content: The AC susceptibility measured at zero field rules out any long-range order: indeed, the imaginary contribution, which shows up below 4 K, is frequency dependent and should thus be attributed to dynamic effects (Figure ). The analysis of the frequency dependence of χ′′ maximum by the Arrhenius law, assuming that at the temperature of the maximum τ = (2πν)−1, yields as best fit values (R 2 = 0.9681) τ0 = (8.6 ± 0.5) 10−11 s and ΔE = 21.4 ± 2 K (inset of Figure ). The physically reasonable values of τ0 and ΔE, even if obtained in a somewhat restricted range of frequencies, rule out the possibility that the system is a spin glass and suggest that FeIII 2CoII is behaving as a SCM at low temperature. It is, however, to be noted that the ratio between real (χ′) and imaginary (χ′′) components of the susceptibility is very large (see for frequency dependent χ′ data), suggesting either a broad distribution of relaxation times, which would also explain the broadness of the observed maxima in χ′′ (Figure ), or that only a fraction of the chains is showing slow relaxation of the magnetization. This may also explain the somehow small value of the barrier ΔE to the reversal of the magnetization, compared to the expectations based on static magnetic measurements. Indeed, in a SCM this parameter is related to the strength of the exchange interaction by the relation ΔE = 4J/kT. Thus, the relatively small ΔE value obtained here would point out a relatively weak magnetic interaction (ca. 5 K), in contrast with the χT versus T data, indicating sizable exchange magnetic interactions are active between FeIII and CoII centers even at room temperature.

elements.content: The results obtained in this study confirm that substitution of either MII or MIII metal centers in this new class of multifunctional hybrid mixed metal oxalates based on the second-order NLO chromophore [DAMS+] does not alter the layered structure of these systems. In such crystalline network, hydrogen bonds involving DAMBA and water molecules play a major role in stabilizing inorganic chains of metal oxalates and allow an efficient control of the segregation of layers of [DAMS+] chromophores self-organized in a head-to-tail disposition, forming NLO efficient J aggregates. This has the very important consequence of maintaining a strong SHG efficiency, which is provided by the organic layer, irrespectively of the metal ions employed.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The results obtained in this study confirm that substitution of either MII or MIII metal centers in this new class of multifunctional hybrid mixed metal oxalates based on the second-order NLO chromophore [DAMS+] does not alter the layered structure of these systems. In such crystalline network, hydrogen bonds involving DAMBA and water molecules play a major role in stabilizing inorganic chains of metal oxalates and allow an efficient control of the segregation of layers of [DAMS+] chromophores self-organized in a head-to-tail disposition, forming NLO efficient J aggregates. This has the very important consequence of maintaining a strong SHG efficiency, which is provided by the organic layer, irrespectively of the metal ions employed.

elements.content: A tuning of the magnetic properties of these mixed metal oxalates by suitable substitution of metal ion centers was then systematically pursued. In particular, previous studies had shown that the substitution of MnII centers by NiII may lead to largely different intrachain exchange interactions while maintaining the superior second order NLO properties. It was then obvious to extend our investigation to CoII based systems, to analyze the effect of an expected largely anisotropic metal ions on the magnetic properties of these systems. A summary in terms of the nature of intrachain exchange magnetic interactions is reported in Table , where previously reported data on MnII and NiII based systems are also collected.

It was then obvious to extend our investigation to CoII based systems, to analyze the effect of an expected largely anisotropic metal ions on the magnetic properties of these systems. A summary in terms of the nature of intrachain exchange magnetic interactions is reported in Table , where previously reported data on MnII  and NiII  based systems are also collected.

The first point to be noted concerns the RhIII 2CoII compound, whose magnetic data show that high spin octacoordinated CoII centers behave similarly to the hexacoordinated CoII ones, being dominated by a large orbital contribution. Moreover, data in Table evidence that virtually no exchange coupling interactions between CoII centers is observed in this case, in similarity with the RhIII 2MnII compound and at variance with the RhIII 2NiII one. The analysis of the magnetic behavior of the CrIII 2CoII compound points out that this system is characterized, as already observed for the corresponding MnII and NiII ones, by ferromagnetic MIII−MII interactions. The most relevant result obtained in the present investigation concerns the FeIII 2CoII compound, characterized by a moderate antiferromagnetic interaction between FeIII and CoII, resulting in a ferrimagnetic like structure. Its low temperature dynamic magnetic properties make this compound a candidate as the second oxalate-based SCM reported up to date, a property which in this case is coupled to the strong second order NLO activity. Our observation confirms the fundamental role of CoII centers in giving rise to a 1D system with SCM behavior. As a further extension of this work we are currently planning the introduction of the MnIII ion which is well-known to provide strong Ising-type anisotropy, an important feature to obtain SCM behavior at a higher temperature.

cln_elements.content:
In a 100 mL two-necked flask [DAMS]I (183.2 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated at 60 °C, and 0.5 mmol K3[M(C2O4)3]·nH2O (M = Rh, Fe, Cr), previously dissolved in 20 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), were added. The heating was turned off, and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (145.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), dissolved in CH3OH (2−3 mL), was added to the still hot solution. A brownish-black precipitate separated immediately as phase αMIII/CoII. After 1 h 30 min stirring at room temperature the solid was filtered, washed with a few drops of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), and dried under vacuum. Attempts to grow suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction failed. Phases αMIII/CoII were characterized by XRPD and found corresponding to αMIII/MII (MIII = Rh, Cr, Fe; MII = Zn, Mn, Ni).

[M<sub>2</sub>Co(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>6</sub>][DAMS]<sub>4</sub>[DAMBA]<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (M = Cr, Fe)

In a 100 mL flask DAMBA (20.5 mg; 0.14 mmol) was added to the corresponding αCrIII/CoII or αFeIII/CoII phase (80.0 mg), prepared as above-reported, dissolved in 70 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated under reflux for 1 h 30 min and then cooled at room temperature. On standing overnight, the formation of a dark compound with a metallic luster was observed. After filtration, the compound was dried under vacuum. Crystals of FeIII 2CoII suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by leaving the solution at room temperature for 3 days.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Phases αMIII/CoII (M = Cr, Fe, Rh)

In a 100 mL two-necked flask [DAMS]I (183.2 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated at 60 °C, and 0.5 mmol K3[M(C2O4)3]⋅nH2O (M = Rh, Fe, Cr), previously dissolved in 20 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), were added. The heating was turned off, and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (145.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), dissolved in CH3OH (2-3 mL), was added to the still hot solution. A brownish-black precipitate separated immediately as phase αMIII/CoII. After 1 h 30 min stirring at room temperature the solid was filtered, washed with a few drops of H2O/CH3OH (1:1), and dried under vacuum. Attempts to grow suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction failed. Phases αMIII/CoII were characterized by XRPD and found corresponding to αMIII/MII (MIII = Rh, Cr, Fe; MII = Zn, Mn, Ni). 

[M2Co(C2O4)6][DAMS]4[DAMBA]2⋅2H2O (M = Cr, Fe)

In a 100 mL flask DAMBA (20.5 mg; 0.14 mmol) was added to the corresponding αCrIII/CoII or αFeIII/CoII phase (80.0 mg), prepared as above-reported, dissolved in 70 mL of H2O/CH3OH (1:1). The solution was heated under reflux for 1 h 30 min and then cooled at room temperature. On standing overnight, the formation of a dark compound with a metallic luster was observed. After filtration, the compound was dried under vacuum. Crystals of FeIII 2CoII suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by leaving the solution at room temperature for 3 days.

View, along the crystallographic a axis, of the inorganic/organic layer (top), and of the relative organization of the [DAMS+] molecules (bottom). Gray, Carbon atoms; Red, oxygen atoms; Blue, nitrogen atoms; Green, MII sites; Yellow, MIII sites. Hydrogen atoms are not shown, for the sake of clarity. The three independent oxalates (1, 2, and 3) are indicated, as well as the stronger hydrogen bonding connections, that involve the “lateral” oxalate ligands (having two free oxygens), the DAMBA molecules, and the water molecules. Weaker C−H---O connections are not represented. Two metal-oxalate stripes, elongated along the direction of the c crystallographic axis, can be recognized.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  View, along the crystallographic a axis, of the inorganic/organic layer (top), and of the relative organization of the [DAMS+] molecules (bottom). Gray, Carbon atoms; Red, oxygen atoms; Blue, nitrogen atoms; Green, MII sites; Yellow, MIII sites. Hydrogen atoms are not shown, for the sake of clarity. The three independent oxalates (1, 2, and 3) are indicated, as well as the stronger hydrogen bonding connections, that involve the "lateral" oxalate ligands (having two free oxygens), the DAMBA molecules, and the water molecules. Weaker C-H---O connections are not represented. Two metal-oxalate stripes, elongated along the direction of the c crystallographic axis, can be recognized.

cln_elements.content: (Top) View, along the crystallographic b axis, of the layered structure formed by the [DAMS+] layers and the inorganic/organic layers. The layers are alternatively charged with positive and negative charges. (Bottom) View of the layered crystal structure along the crystallographic c axis, showing the packing of two layers and the disposition of the oxalate-based chains in the structure. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
